spanishExample: ¿Quieres dar una vuelta? Me da lo mismo.
englishTranslation: Do you want to go for a walk? It’s all the same to me.
vocabIncluded: me da lo mismo: "it's all the same to me" (idiom)

spanishExample: Da *good advice* mientras estamos de camino.
englishTranslation: Give good advice while we’re on the way.

spanishExample: Dale lo que te dijimos.
englishTranslation: Give him what we told you.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Dame las cosas después.
englishTranslation: Give me the things afterwards.

spanishExample: Di la verdad para que te den algo.
englishTranslation: Tell the truth so that they give you something.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Dicen que para entonces se lo van a dar.
englishTranslation: They say that by then they are going to give it to him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Dijiste que no querías darle *the answers.*
englishTranslation: You said you didn’t want to give him the answers.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dime si tengo que hacerle caso de nuevo.
englishTranslation: Tell me if I have to pay attention to him anew.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Él dice que tú das *free food.*
englishTranslation: He says that you give free food.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ella me da *food* y tú me das *drinks.*
englishTranslation: She gives me food and you give me drinks.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Le damos el caso al *officer* después de este problema.
englishTranslation: We’re giving the case to the officer after this problem.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Les decía eso antes.
englishTranslation: I was telling them that before.
vocabIncluded: decía: "was saying", "I was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 1st person)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Mañana te daré algo más.
englishTranslation: Tomorrow I’ll give you something else.
vocabIncluded: daré: "will give", "I will give" (Dar, future, 1st person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Me dieron sus cosas tarde.
englishTranslation: They gave me their things late.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Mientras das la vuelta, yo voy a hacer esto.
englishTranslation: While you take the walk, I’m going to do this.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: No me diste nada.
englishTranslation: You didn’t give me anything.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: No quiero que le des esto a mi amigo.
englishTranslation: I don’t want you to give this to my friend.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Nos dan esto, pero no quieren que se lo demos a nadie.
englishTranslation: They are giving us this, but they don’t want us to give it to anyone.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Me dará de vuelta lo que le dimos.
englishTranslation: He will give me back what we gave him.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
dará: "will give", "he/she/it will give" (Dar, future, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Quiere que yo les dé algo.
englishTranslation: She wants me to give them something.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Quiero que ella te dé esas cosas de esta manera.
englishTranslation: I want her to give you those things in this manner.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Quiero que usted les dé algo.
englishTranslation: I want you (formal) to give them something.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: Si les doy esto, entonces tendrán que darte algo.
englishTranslation: If I give them this, then they will have to give you something.
vocabIncluded: les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
tendrán: "will have", "they will have" (Tener, future, 3rd person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Si lo haces, entonces te voy a dar *a reward.*
englishTranslation: If you do it, then I am going to give you a reward.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Tengo que decirte que no lo he dado de vuelta.
englishTranslation: I have to tell you that I haven’t given it back.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que darme algo antes de esa semana.
englishTranslation: You have to give me something before that week.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que decirme cuál fue la pregunta.
englishTranslation: You have to tell me what the question was.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Todavía les estoy dando *lunch.*
englishTranslation: I’m still giving them lunch.
vocabIncluded: les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Yo les di *the notebooks* y ella les dio *the pencils.*
englishTranslation: I gave them the notebooks and she gave them the pencils.
vocabIncluded: les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
